page.title: 13Royal Hartley Bottle Works
page.content: In 1763 the Royal Hartley Bottle Works were opened. They were built by Sir Francis Delaval. The first glass house was 200 feet long, 52 feet wide and the walls were 36 feet high. Just after the bottle works were opened Sir Francis travelled to Hanover in Germany to obtain some advice on glass making. He came back with german employees to teach the Hartley people how to make glass. This is what we call the Hanover connection. Nearby a brickworks was being established to help the bottle workers, but still there was a demand for sandstone which kept the quarrymen busy every day. As the industry grew it was decided to extend the premises.
